attributes.title: Hasbro's Magic: The Gathering Franchise Is Poised For Immense Growth Long Term
summary: 'Magic: The Gathering' propels the toys and games segment, along with 'Monopoly'.
The release of the 'Eternal Masters' set suggests the company's decision to cater to a greater demographic audience.
The digital plan outlined for 2017 will attack the market at every demographic, capitalizing on the story line and eventual franchise movie.
There are still risks with the satisfaction of the majority long-term customer base.

attributes.content:
Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS) is in the business of creating toys and games that cater to an audience that craves a story-driven experience for young people through adults, according to CEO Brian Golder. This is a distinct difference between the company and its closest rival, Mattel (MAT). One of Hasbro's best stories that is a game is Magic: The Gathering. In the past, it has propelled the games segment of the company, and in the future has some massive potential to imitate the success of Transformers (company-owned) and Star Wars (licensed from Disney (DIS)) toys and merchandise with an upcoming Magic: The Gathering movie.

Source: Magic

Yet, there is a belief that technology is outpacing traditional toys in youth, and that soldiers, dolls, and cars are largely being replaced by parents supplying their children with tablets and smartphones. Even so, a traditional trading card game continues to grow in sales and popularity in 2016. How Hasbro continues to cater to the growing Magic: The Gathering audience in varying age groups and locales will have an impact on the future of this valuable asset.

The reality is that Magic: The Gathering is growing and comprises a powerful segment of Hasbro's line of toys and games. Last year's 4Q saw Battle for Zendikar become the company's most successful release in its more than twenty years in business. Currency differences aside, Magic: The Gathering also propelled an 8% gain in the games category with help from the Monopoly franchise. I expect the latest expansion set, Oath of the Gatewatch, to overtake that position, and the April 2016 release of Shadows over Innistrad to overtake that due to a stellar marketing campaign.

Eternal Masters and Catering to the Trading Card Community

Investors should note that Wizards of the Coast (maker of Magic: The Gathering, and wholly owned by Hasbro) just made a powerful gesture to its community with news of the release of Eternal Masters this summer. The set is designed to bridge the gap between a format of competitive play known as Legacy and the growing cost of cards necessary for playing in that format.

The new set will reprint cards that have been seen as largely essential to playing the format and, in many cases, can range between $50 and $5,000 each, while at the same time respecting the secondary market by only printing a limited run of this set.

There exists a reserved list of cards from the early days of Magic: The Gathering that are far too valuable that Wizards of the Coast has refused to reprint in order to protect the secondary market for those cards. It is a legally binding agreement that actually saved the game from extinction in the mid-'90s. You can read a lengthy discussion of that matter here.

Even still, the two teaser cards revealed to be part of the Eternal Masters set (Force of Will and Wasteland) will also pump life into other more casual formats, such as EDH (Commander) and Cube. Once a casual unsanctioned format, Wizards is steadily introducing a number of products directly towards this audience. It is not uncommon to find players of this format who do not buy the other products. This continues to illustrate the effort made to reach different audiences with the same game and story. Its player base is much smaller, but has been growing year-after-year.

The implications of this new expansion set (Eternal Masters) are incredible and should not be understated. The player base for Magic: The Gathering is a wonderful demographic for Hasbro, as more than 75% of its customers comprise the 18-40 age group. This set directly targets the younger demographic by offering them an opportunity to buy a booster pack or box that might contain a powerful card they could never afford before the release. It also directly targets the older demographic by catering to their need to have these necessary cards reprinted for competitive formats, not limited to gaming stores, but also tournaments attended by thousands.

Hasbro is Learning to Cater to Every Audience at the Digital Level

Yes, there were some hiccups with Magic: The Gathering Online that propelled a significant distaste in the medium. Rather than ignore the problem, Hasbro has learned from it, and is now in the process of developing a digital plan that will cater to every single digital need customers have with the introduction of a new product known only as Magic Digital Next, to be released in 2017. The goal is to capture an interested lead and cater to their entertainment needs with one online medium, while continuing to impress the long-term customer base.

Hasbro learned a powerful lesson in the storytelling segment of its franchise when it abandoned print books for Magic: The Gathering and switched to ebooks. Eventually, the company abandoned ebooks and diverted that energy to Duels of the Planeswalkers a Steam-based game that is played on conventional gaming devices such as the Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox or Sony's (SNE) PlayStation and even personal computers and capable tablets. The game pairs the highly desirable elements of a conventional RPG with a far less static version of the card game. Again, Hasbro is successfully tapping into an audience which may not otherwise be familiar with its popular trading card game.

Rather than continuing to force the print novel and ebook segment, which was insufficient for customers who still craved the story line segment (which is Hasbro's specialty), and was largely unprofitable, Hasbro has a plan that will cater to the customer's desire for a story, while likely bringing in many more new customers that have only casually played Magic: The Gathering, and those who have never played at all.

I've already written about the power of the upcoming movie franchise produced by Fox (FOX, FOXA). Based on the wide range in the demographic and the norm of epic fantasy entertainment (Lord of the Rings and Game of Thrones) Magic: The Gathering has the potential in the long term for sequels and prequels.

Risks in the Secondary Market and the Value of Cards

Even with all of the growth prospects in alternative games and a movie franchise, it is important to be aware of the secondary market for cards, which is an industry of speculation and investment in and of itself. Various blogs, forums, and even premium subscription services cater to a demand to speculate on valuable and powerful cards that Wizards of the Coast has produced.

Not every single Magic: The Gathering card is valuable on the secondary market - far from it. Still, many cards retain value as their demand outweighs the supply in need for tournaments, casual play, and speculation that they will be desired in the near or far future.

Thus, the market of Magic: The Gathering customers is heavily reliant on the prospect of cards retaining or gaining in value. The purchasing of booster boxes in droves is a testament to that, and makes for a game-of-chance effect for those players as they hope to crack open a pack (36 packs are in a box) containing a highly desirable card that they can sell or trade up for. Players will be less likely to take that risk and buy in droves if there is no perception that the cards will maintain or possibly gain in financial value.

In addition, a growing number of players have vocalized their mistrust and distaste for what is perceived as price gouging and insider information on the reprinting of valuable cards, allowing prominent vendors to quietly buy or unload a given card before the official release by Wizards. It's important to note that these are allegations, and there is no proof as to who is responsible for leaks of product data, and whether vendors are actually receiving insider information. However small, the growing distrust is worth mentioning.

Thus, Wizards maintains the task of not only producing captivating story lines and compelling game play, but of delivering cards that are thought to be valuable both from their game play and their rarity. Lately, it has done an exceptional job at this with what are known as "Expedition Lands." These are very limited reprints of successful and valuable cards from past sets with holofoil and full artwork. With no guarantee of receiving one in a booster box, players are scrambling to find these cards (buying more product) that are often retailing on the secondary market for several hundred dollars each!

Conclusion

Let's not forget, though, that much of the appeal in Magic: The Gathering is the balanced card game that heavily relies on skill, in which cards are carefully and thoughtfully produced. Customers continue to come back to the game because Wizards can reliably deliver a stellar product that appeals to so many - through the story, in the artwork, with powerful cards, and a healthy secondary market. Now it is delivering on an electronic level, and soon with Fox's movie franchise. I believe Hasbro is in for a real treat with this franchise, and it has a lot of room to run in the long term.

I invite you take a look at the marketing efforts Wizards of the Coast is introducing this year, and how they are planning for a stellar spring and summer release, which is notoriously a slow time for trading card games. Besides Eternal Masters, fans are anxious as Wizards is revealing spoilers of Shadows over Innistrad with a teasing trickle effect, simultaneously utilizing escape rooms and live puzzles on three different continents. The Twitter hashtag #MTGSOI is full of positive reviews from veteran players, and is loaded with speculation and excitement.
